Data Sources

Data Source 1 - Public Transit Ridership from American Public Transportation Association

This data source contains national information on quarterly public transit ridership and serves as a good baseline time series to explain the problem of decreasing ridership, as well as how ridership seems to be trending. The dataset has ridership numbers for heavy rail, light rail, commuter rail, trolleybus, bus, and other, making it a good candidate for analyzing as univariate or multivariate. It can be interesting to analyze the difference in trends between transit method, which may inform conclusions on how or why ridership is trending a certain way. This will also be used in the deep learning section.

Source

Data Source 2 - City-Specific Public Transit Ridership Data

All Cities

The Federal Transit Administration (FTA) provides monthly public transit ridership data for every U.S. metropolitan area where applicable. Data regarding total passenger trips and miles will be used to hone in on specific cities and analyze disparities. In this dataset, we will select some of the top cities in public transit ridership to focus on areas with a greater affected population.

Source

In addition to this, we will look at daily data from two of the top three cities in public transit ridership: New York City and Chicago. The purpose of this will be to get a greater understanding of how people use public transit on a daily or weekly level, which could tell us more about what influences people’s transportation decisions.

New York City

Source

Chicago

Source

Data Source 3 - Rideshare Usage

As an alternative to public transit, rideshare services such as Uber and Lyft have become increasingly popular. Data regarding their usage will be used to analyze the relationship between different transportation options and get a better sense of how consumer behavior has evolved. This data specifically contains quarterly time steps of users.

Uber Source

Lyft Source

Data Source 4 - Vehicle Usage

Similar to rideshare usage, this will serve as a way to understand the extent to which people are selecting alternatives to public transit. This time series contains monthly data on total automobile miles driven nationally, as provided by the U.S. Federal Highway Administration via FRED.

Source

Data Source 5 - Gas Prices

Once again, this data is included due to our interest in alternatives to public transit. Gas prices can have a great effect on people’s inclination to use private transportation, so they may be valuable as an exogenous variable in multivariate analysis. This time series contains monthly average gas prices and comes from the U.S. Energy Information Administration.

Source

Data Source 6 - Financial Data

The following financial datasets will be used in this project:

  • Rideshare Companies’ Stocks (Uber, Lyft)
  • Telecommunications Companies’ Stocks (Microsoft, Zoom, Cisco)
  • Oil Companies’ Stocks (Exxon, Chevron, BP, Shell)

These can be analyzed in the financial time series section, and provide valuable insight into the interplay between human behavior and economic conditions. They can also address angles relating to work-from-home and financial viability of regularly using public transit, which undoubtedly have a large impact on ridership. Finally, the coinciding of these financial assets’ behavior during COVID-19 with the decrease in ridership can be further analyzed.

The financial data will be gathered using the getSymbols() function from the quantmod package in R.

Data Source 7 - Remote Work Data from Bureau of Labor Statistics

This data source contains time series data on remote work, giving us information on the proportion of Americans that work from home and thus do not necessarily need transportation on a daily basis. This will have significant interaction with COVID-19, as well as act as a partial explanation for why public transit ridership may be lower in more recent years.

Source

Data Source 8 - Unemployment Rates

A monthly unemployment rate time series will be used to further analyze the relationship between commuters and their transportation choices. As stated above, a large portion of public transit ridership is a result of commuting to work, so this could be an important consideration as an exogenous variables for multivariate analysis. This data is provided by U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics via FRED.

Source

Data Acquisition

Since all of these data sources (except for the financial data) come from downloadable online datasets, data is acquired first by downloading it and saving as a .csv file in a data folder. The Data Visualization section contains R code that reads in the data with the read_csv() function and performs any necessary augmentation in order to perform time series analysis. Cleaned data is then saved in the data folder for further use.
